Day 3 complete, yay! This practice was exactly what I needed today. I am in a period of transition in my life, where my fear of letting people in is slowly slipping away and I am letting go of my past neuroses, negative thoughts, and loneliness. With this new openness and connectedness I am experiencing comes an officious voice of dread that says I will never be good enough for any of it. New experiences and new people are coming into my life, which I am so grateful for, but at the same time it all strikes a familiar fear into my heart and the urge to perform for these people or things, or to cower away from them, often comes to the surface.

Spending this time on the mat, connecting with my breath, feeling the energy flow within me and really paying attention to the nuances within my body, and knowing that others are on a similar, beautiful journey, all helps me to realise the weight of what I've carried throughout my life and what I no longer need to carry. Thank you, Adriene, for your amazing presence here and for this soul-serving series!

P.S. I am really excited to listen to your upcoming conversation with Russell Brand!

I Keep coming back. It's not just a good workout... the Breath helps me to hear my inner self, my inner life and Spirit.

Today, when Adriene asked us to speak lovingly to ourselves... I felt an overwhelming feeling that it's ok to love yourself, even while I'm so imperfect in so many ways, it's ok to love myself and be kind to myself.

Then... when she talked about the miniscule muscles we're are using with our breath... it reminded me of the lesson on cells I was giving to my kids... how we have trillions of tiny cells composing our body, little universes within my body working hard to give me life and energy... and I felt grateful for all the hard work, all the life, all the joy, all the stretching and reaching in the middle of the opposition of life that my body has given.
And I thought... it's ok to love my body...
Not like I love my body because of whatever shape it's in(which is fine), but I love it because of everything it gives me and does for me. Constantly.

See. It's not just a physical workout. It's something more. And I'm incredibly grateful for that.

What I love about home practice in general and Adriene specifically is that it's ok if I can't do the whole routine some days.  My knees aren't great, and some days the lunges are too much and I sit on the mat and do ground poses until we can "meet" in a pose I'm feeling up to. Thank you, thank you, thank you Adriene!!! I am on a healing journey, have been for about 5 or so years. I was relinquished for adoption at birth. This trauma and the subsequent trauma of being placed into a new and different family impacted me spiritually, physically, and emotionally. My body has stored that trauma until now. My adoptive parents chose to not tell me about being adopted because they said I was a very sensitive child. They had 2 biological children right after I was placed with them. They did not wish for me to feel less loved and wanted than my brother and my sister. But even though I did not have the knowledge of my relinquishment or my adoption, my body knew.  A confusing place to be for sure. At 20 years old I accidentally found out that I was adopted. The impact of this knowledge is difficult to describe. Honestly, for the next 25 years I think I was in shock from this new information about myself and my reality. Denial is a powerful thing, it was my native language. Anyway, recently I have been working with a somatic experience therapist trying to learn how to be more "in my body." I was completely disconnected from my body, my feelings, and my self. She is an incredibly gifted therapist and has helped me tremendously in learning how to experience my feelings that I have always up until about 5 years ago kept numb because I did not think I could feel them and survive. SE therapy and yoga (with breath work and mindfulness) have changed my life. As an adoptee, being in my body has always felt unsafe. I am slowly learning how and experiencing being grounded and growing in feeling safe. The slow, gentle, patient, and endearing way that you lead yoga is enabling me to actually feel relaxed in my body. Hyper-vigilance is one more gift that my relinquishment gave to me. I have tried so many different ways to not hold my breath and my body so tense, but I have had no success until yoga. But who you are and how you speak and what you draw attention to is like magic. It truly is a balm and an aide assisting my body to not hold the tension. Thank you.

Wave breathing.
I awake.
I am silently weeping.
In frustration.Â  In fear. In loneliness.
I console myself that I know for a fact
I am not alone.
That countless souls are just as I.
I recall today's practice.
Of wave breathing.
As a way to turn my gaze inwards.
My weeping stops.
It is enough.

Namaste Adriene! I feel so happy to have learned this new Ujjayi breath from you. At first, I felt that I could not get it, but I kept practising. Also, I watched your recommended video to learn more before todayâ€™s class, which helped (practise before practise, lol).

My Ujjayi breath with my mouth closed was quite exaggerated, and I made all kinds of odd sounds, including a gurgling sound in the back of my throat. Then, I realized that maybe I was trying too hard (a usual problem for me, along with forgetting to breath). So my breath became a whisper soft form of Ha, of the way that I did it with my mouth open. I felt so gently happy with this outcome. ğŸ˜Š

I also found your visual of my breath fogging up a window when my mouth was open, with a heart drawn on the glass, to be so appealing. It became a good visual image and memory cue for me, for how I could make it happen again, once I caught on. So I mentally repeated this, a few times.

Also, it was a great challenge for me, to sync up the breath with movement. So in order to keep my focus on new breath going as much as possible, I found that I need to do the movements very gentle today. Which was good as I am sore and tired. I also incorporated many mods, inspired by all the wonderful modification advice, kindly posted by people who took yesterdayâ€™s class. Namaste all!

Question, is part of the breath technique also restricting a little on the inhale as well? Or only the exhale?
Yes, both.

Inhale slightly deeper than normal through your nose. Exhale slowly through your nose while constricting the muscles in the back of your throat. If you slightly constrict your muscles,Â the inhales can be compared to the sound the ocean makes as the water is gathering up to form the wave, the exhales can be compared to the sound of the waves crashing to the shore.

I can totally relate. I started doing Yoga last year and I started with another of the 30day challenges with Adriene and I could only do 10 to 15 min of practice.
I dont know if this helps you but what I did was take breaths. I would pause to video and take 5 long breaths. When it felt my body just couldnt do it any longer I stopped and promise myself to come back another day and finish it. This practices have been long but something that could help when there are short practices is complement the practice with one from Adriene's foundations series so you can better understand the pose.
Also if you dont want to quit the video you can stop when your body is done and wait in corpse pose to the end. The important thing is to show up, as she says, is to get your body to the mat cause with just that movement you are fullfiling your commitment to your body.
I hope this aids you a little going forward and it isnt to preachy. I just relate cause I literally didnt do any type of movement before this.

As always, thank you for this lovely practice. For anyone like me who has asthma, Ujjayi breath can be a little helpful at slowing and potentially preventing an oncoming asthma attack when it's triggered by activity. When I hike, I always make sure I have my inhaler handy (as you should too!) -- but I have noticed that if I start to struggle with breath on a steep incline, I can stop and often calm my lungs down until I can get a full breath again, using Ujjayi breath. Something to try and see if it helps you too. (Obviously, you know your own asthma and if you are past the point of no return, use the inhaler or get help! But using this technique may help you, as it's helped me, to reduce my inhaler needs.)

Here's how Ujjayi breath changed my life. Because of my deviated septum I used to have a cold every winter, several times a year actually. And I was used to struggle with breathing during very hot, humid summers, and when doing exercise, and when it was cold and...well, you get the gist. Since I started practicing Ujjayi breath I slowly ceased to have all these issues. I haven't had a cold in two years now, and every time I find myself struggling with breathing I turn to Ujjayi and it literally opens my lungs and nasal cavity. Where lots of medicines and thermal baths failed, simple breathing made it.

During day 1 and 2, I found it difficult for me to really take deep breaths and focus on my movement and breath, because I've been going through a lot of anxiety and OCD and my mind couldn't help but wander into dark places, no matter how hard I tried to focus on the practice. When breathing in, it felt like I was stuck at a certain point, as if my body or mind didn't allow me to breathe in any further. Today I still had troubling thoughts but felt much lighter when stepping onto the mat. I really loved that we were practicing ocean breath today because it was new to me and I focused on it much more. I smiled a lot throughout the practice. By the end of the video,  I was able to take the longest breath I've taken for quite some time now, I think. I was surprised how I wasn't stuck at a certain point and instead really felt the air I was soaking in through my entire body. It felt like the biggest physical relieve after days of battling my anxious and intrusive thoughts. I feel so light now, Adriene. Thank you so much from the bottom of my heart â¤ï¸

Our dear friend Graham has needed a ventilator to take his breaths for nearly three weeks now. He was my favorite DAWG today. To all who read this comment, please take a moment to send out a positive thought or prayer for our "buddy-bud" Graham. <3 Thanks, Adriene, for creating this beautiful environment in which we are encouraged to take care of ourselves and send loving thoughts to each other. Your explanation of the ujjayi breath bubbled up a wonderful childhood memory of a conch shell I used to listen to whenever I would visit the bookshelves in my grandmother's basement.

Thanks to everyone who commented here in support of our buddy bud, our dear friend Graham, who has now joined the angels. The day he transitioned, I was a day behind in the journey (having stayed two days on the super yummy "Snuggle"), and that day I did "Connect," which had the first knocking on heaven's door that I remembered in Breath. Instead of giggles, there were tears, but also a smile and acknowledgement that we are all connected and there was no coincidence in that timing. I am filled with gratitude for the love and dedication that flows through this community. Thank you! ğŸ’“ğŸ™

I love that the focus is on breath! For the last five years in a row, I've had a seasonal asthmatic cough that starts in the Fall and ends in the Spring. It's been frustrating and constant and a whole bunch of different meds have done almost nothing to control it. I started a daily practice with Adriene over three months ago just after my cough showed up, and within a few weeks, the cough was gone with no sign of it since! I spoke to my doctor about it and she believes that all the breath work Adriene has taught me basically worked as therapy on my lungs. She got incredibly excited to recommend this to other patients, and is going to start doing yoga with Adriene herself. I'm so grateful for this practice for so many reasons but I wanted to share this one small thing that has made such a big difference in my quality of life.  Thank you for all you given me, Adriene!

Day 3: oh, this one felt GOOD.

I had to stop and start three different times during the first eight minutes of practice because of other things going on, and even as I was finally settling in, I found myself wondering, am I going to manage to keep focus at all? And then I started picturing the ocean.
Keeping focus is SO HARD for me with yoga sometimes! I can take my body through the movements, but being present in the moment is so difficult. But today, I found myself visualizing some combination of every beach I've ever visited in my life, the swell of waves up and down, for the whole practice. Sometimes I was still as a rock with the waves crashing around me. Sometimes I was laying on the beach listening. Sometimes I was the water. But it WORKED. I was here with the practice rather than off in my head churning over anxieties or other things, not distracting myself by focusing too much on Trying To Focus. Things flowed together. I didn't keep getting messed up because Adriene's breathing rhythm was slightly different than my own, because it was easy to picture the ocean just changing tempo a little and flowing with it. I kept plank pose way easier than usual (way longer than yesterday!) because I wasn't concentrating on trying SO HARD to keep all my muscles in place, I was just being a steady pier surrounded by water.

Heck. If I can keep remembering this technique, I think I can DO this.

So... I have this anxiety when it comes to audible breath. I think it started when I was a kid and I was a mouth breather LOL. My anxiety got worse  when I went into theatre school and all we did for the first year was focus on the breath. Theatre school was a competitive environment and I would constantly perform with my breath, because well... it was theatre school. Anywho! What Adriene said about the Ocean Breath not about performing, it really resonated with me. I find that I perform for others and myself a bunch. So to allow myself to find this time to let that go was so satisfying, albeit scary. Thank you for this wonderful day three. Can't wait for tomorrow!

Hey Adriene,

Long time viewer of yours but recently something has been brought to my attention. Yoga being â€œtaughtâ€ by white people is cultural appropriation. Iâ€™m ashamed to say that I wasnâ€™t aware of this until today and I havenâ€™t been able to put my phone down since I came to this realization because I am having one consistent thought continuously swirling around in my mind â€œhow did I not know this sooner.â€ My phone is no longer being used today for social media, calls, or texts, Iâ€™m using my phone today to start on my research journey of yoga and cultural appropriation specifically, in the United States. I encourage you to do some thinking and research on this topic yourself being that you have such a large platform with SO many viewers and subscribers. I am concerned that your not aware of this and I hope I can raise awareness by typing out this comment to you. Itâ€™s my job as a white person to raise awareness to other white people...itâ€™s your job as well. I really hope you read this.

This is the first time I am trying to do the the 30 day series in 30 days. I am really enjoying it but my wrists are not. I have had problems with my wrists and elbows before. Today I could not do all the downward facing dog poses. I took breaks and modified a little. Any suggestions for the days to come?  I am afraid if it gets worse I wonâ€™t be able to continue. ğŸ™
Thank you so much for your encouragement!  I, too, will spend time in child pose instead of downward facing dog to give my wrists a break. I will remind myself to show up and breathe.

I'm by no means an expert, but I do have trouble with my wrists and now shoulder due to injury and what has worked for me is to try the pose as is first then modify as my body tells me it's approaching its limit. I've spent many times in child pose as a result or doing plank with my knees down. But with time, my wrists have slowly gotten stronger. I always modify as a general rule to meet my body where it is, but this series specifically is excellent for mods because the focus is the breath. So I figure as long as I'm breathing and staying in my body, it's OK if some days I spend the entire practice in child pose and mountain pose. As cliche as it sounds, the point really is the journey. Hope you are able to continue yours. Sending lots of positive healing vibes to you.

Is there a foundations of â€œcomfortable seatâ€.  Even seated on a blanket, it is not comfortable in my hips.

It took me a really long time to become comfortable sitting on the floor and occasionally my back is still unhappy about it. On those days, I simply lay down instead (there's also the option to sit on a chair/couch, though I personally prefer to keep close to the mat).

But generally, I think it just takes the body some getting used to (and the more flexible I get with yoga, the more comfortable it is as well).

It might be helpful to begin each session with a bit of sitting so your body can start getting used to it, then transition to lying down when it gets too uncomfortable. From there, you can increase the amount of time you stay in a seat each day.

I was recently diagnosed with GERD, have had years of hip and lower back pain, migraines and a combo of other ailments... I started yoga by watching your videos and now do three sessions a week and am feeling so much better in all departments. Thatâ€™s amazing!

@Ben thank you Ben for your response ğŸ™ğŸ» itâ€™s very helpful to hear of your journey and yes yoga really is a journey that deepens us into this awareness of our body, the spaciousness and tightness and the pains we may not have been aware of. I am aware of the spiritual significance of the hips also as storage spaces for emotional pain so that is interesting to delve into. Iâ€™ve advised her as youâ€™ve wisely said to move into childâ€™s pose and to move slow throughout and hopefully this will allow flexibility and openness in these tense areas to deepen. Aloha. In gratitude for the journey ğŸ˜Š
@Erica mee :) Mahalo
@TT Thanks for the tip, I will!

@Natalie Passant I'm sorry to hear that, that must be very scary and frustrating for her, and you. I started a bit ago and early on was consistently going into child's pose as the movements would advance or sometimes on even basic maneuvers as I built my strength. No shame in taking a moment. I never pushed unless I was ready and tried to remain patient as I grew. Given all my aches and pains, sometimes hidden also, I have been having to learn my body and finding its weaknesses. My hips and joints are very tight and the nerves love to say hello in each session. The good news is in time for me I've seen myself grow stronger, less muscle spasms, nerve reactions, and soreness. My only advice is for her not to push anything that isn't comfortable and allow her body to speak to her comfort. Chiropractic adjustments have helped as well in realignment on areas that have had years of abuse, especially my sciatica and low back. Good luck and I hope the practice helps in time. Aloha
